field_edited_text.value:
MARYLAND’S PRIMARY BRrRIDGE ProGrRAM 5

also indicated that it would approve a modification in the plans submitted,
by reducing the vertical clearance at the west channel crossing from 140
feet to 50 feet. It was determined that 50 feet vertical clearance would be
sufficient at this crossing.

In the case of the Sandy Point-Kent Island Bridge, the State Roads Com-
mission proposed two channel crossings. The War Department has decided
that only one is needed, but has requested that this span be widened to
provide for 1200 feet lateral clearance instead of 1000 feet lateral clearance
proposed, with vertical clearance of 175 feet. Also the location of the
bridge will be shifted south, in order to provide better navigation ap-
proaches to the channel span than was possible at the location proposed
originally, which was very close to the turn in the navigation channel at
Sandy Point Lighthouse.

In the case of the Susquehanna River Bridge, the span lengths are
longer than those originally proposed. These longer spans were dictated
by economical layout requirements, after depth of foundations had been
definitely established by borings.

The War Department modifications in the plans for crossing the Patapsco
River consisted only of changes in the fender system. The proposed 1000
feet horizontal clearance and 175 feet vertical clearance over the channel
has been approved by the War Department.

The Potomac River Bridge has been changed to meet War Department
requirements by increasing the channel span 150 feet in length (from 650
feet to 800 feet) to provide for a clear opening 700 feet wide. The vertical
clearance of 135 feet has not been changed for this structure. The channel
span, however, has been shifted eastward toward the Maryland shore,
which has effected changes in the approach spans which, in addition to the
increased span length, make this bridge a more expensive structure than it
would have been under the original plans.

The State Roads Commission has made two applications to the Federal
Emergency Administration of Public Works for grants to aid in financing
the construction of the four bridges in this program. One application
covers the three bridges in the north-south highway as a single project
herein designated as Project Number 1, including the Susquehanna, Pa-
tapsco, and Potomac River Bridges. See (1), (2), and (3) on Map of
Maryland, showing Arterial Highways—Plate 1.

The other application covers a bridge across the Chesapeake Bay, herein
